courses.name: Intro to Engineering
courses.descr: Introduction to profession, including disciplines of chemical, civil, computer, electrical, environmental, and mechanical engineering. Prepares students for success through integration of: technical problem solving and engineering design, ethical decision-making, teamwork, and communicating to diverse audiences.

courses.name: Intro to Computer Science I
courses.descr: Computing and principles of programming with an emphasis on systematic program design. Topics include functional programming, data abstraction, procedural abstraction, use of control and state, recursion, testing, and object-oriented programming concepts. Requires no prior programming experience, open to any major, but intended primarily for majors and minors in computer science or mathematics.
courses.breadth: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

courses.name: Analytic Geometry & Calculus A
courses.descr: Functions, limits, continuity, derivatives. Polynomial, rational, exponential, hyperbolic, logarithmic, trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions. Definite and indefinite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. Simple differential equations (separable ODE, linear ODE). ODE models leading to exponential growth and decay.
courses.restrict: Students who received credit in MATH242 or MATH243 are not elligble to take this course without permission
courses.breadth: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

courses.name: Seminar in Composition
courses.descr: Introduction to the process of academic writing that centers on the composition of analytical, research-based essays.
courses.restrict: Required of all students. Should be taken first year on campus

courses.name: Race in Society
courses.descr: Examination of the social construction of race and its importance in institutions and social identify. History of race in the United States, including access to rights and privileges and how groups worked for racial equality. and how race structures relationships among diverse groups in society. Includes analysis of rights and privileges denied or extended to groups and how disadvantaged groups work towards racial equality.
courses.breadth: GROUP C: A&S Social Behavioral Sci

courses.name: Intro to Computer Science II
courses.descr: Principles of computer science illustrated and applied through programming in an object oriented language. Programming projects illustrate computational problems, styles and issues that arise in computer systems development and in all application areas of computation.
courses.breadth: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

courses.name: Intro to Systems Programming
courses.descr: Principles of computer systems programming for software and hardware platforms to achieve efficient resource usage. Topics include the C programming language, memory management, and awareness of system constraints and interfacing. Projects include programming embedded systems and interactive objects.

courses.name: Analytic Geometry & Calculus B
courses.descr: Brief review of MATH 241; evaluation of limits by L’Hospital’s rule; applications of integration; integration techniques; parametric curves; polar coordinates; infinite sequences and series. Includes use of computers to perform symbolic, numerical and graphical analysis.
courses.restrict: Students who received credit in MATH243

courses.name: Contemporary Political Ideologies
courses.descr: Considers the theoretical development of liberal democracy and significant theoretical and ideological challenges to its dominance including Marxist, Islamist, postcolonial and postmodernist political theories. Students read the original sources of these positions while considering their historical development and application to contemporary politics.
courses.breadth: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

courses.name: Sexualities & Gender Studies
courses.descr: An exploration of the variations in the social construction of lesbian, gay, bisexual, heterosexual, transsexual, transgender and queer identities and communities in contemporary American society through study of gay literature, history, theory, religious and legal issues and the arts including film, music, television, and visual arts.
courses.breadth: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change AND Multicultural

courses.name: Discrete Mathematics I
courses.descr: Elements of sets and logic. Relations, functions. Integers. Induction and recursion. Principles and techniques of counting. Graphs. Paths and circuits
courses.breadth: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

courses.name: Data Structures
courses.descr: Review of data type abstraction, recursion, arrays, stacks, queues, multiple stacks and linked lists. Emphasis on dynamic storage management, garbage collection, trees, graphs, tables, sorting and searching.

courses.name: Machine Organization & Assembly Language
courses.descr: Introduction to the basics of machine organization. Programming tools and techniques at the machine and assembly levels. Assembly language programming and computer arithmetic techniques.

courses.name: Geological Hazards Lab
courses.descr: Laboratory investigation of environmental geological processes and their impact on society: earthquakes, volcanoes, coastal hazards, rivers and streams, groundwater. Identification of earth materials and study of earth processes using topographical, geological and tectonic maps.
courses.breadth: GROUP D LAB: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Tech w Lab

courses.name: Geological Hazards
courses.descr: Geological processes and events that adversely affect humans and civilization. Methods for predicting and dealing with geological hazards. May be taken with a 1 credit lab, GEOL 115.
courses.breadth: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

courses.name: Analytic Geometry & Calculus C
courses.descr: Vectors, operations on vectors, velocity and acceleration, partial derivatives, directional derivatives, optimization of functions of two or more variables, integration over two and three dimensional regions, line integrals, Green’s Theorem, surface integrals, the Divergence theorem. Includes use of computers to perform symbolic, numerical and graphical analysis.

courses.name: Intro to Woman & Gender Studies
courses.descr: Study of causes and conditions determining women's status in society, as evidenced in institutional structures and personal relations between men and women. Taught from multidisciplinary perspectives.
courses.breadth: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavorial Sci AND Multicultural

courses.name: Intro to Software Engineering
courses.descr: Object oriented software design and development through use of an object oriented programming language. Topics include team programming, design patterns, graphical user interfaces, software engineering tools (e.g., integrated development environments, version control, build management, bug tracking, automated testing).

courses.name: Elementary Linear Algebra
courses.descr: Systems of linear equations, linear combinations of vectors, and matrix algebra. Determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, similarity and diagonalization of square matrices. Vector spaces, linear dependence and independence, basis and dimension, linear transformations. Inner product spaces, orthogonality, orthogonal projections, fundamental subspaces. A software package may be used for the analysis and solution of linear algebra problems.
courses.restrict: Students who received credit in MATH342 or MATH351 are not eligible to take this course without permission

courses.name: Probability Theory & Simulation
courses.descr: Introduces the basic theory of discrete and continuous aspects of probability theory. Topics include bivariate distributions, sums of independent random variables, moment generating functions, laws of large numbers and central limit theorem.
courses.restrict: Requires basic knowledge of the counting principles in permutation and combination

courses.name: Technical Writing
courses.descr: Selected problems in technical communications, the preparation of reports and technical editing.

courses.name: Assistive Technology Seminar
courses.descr: SEMINAR
